awd_titl_txt: Advancing Understanding of Solar Flares With Microwave Imaging Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar flares are the largest explosions in the solar system that release huge amounts of energy. Flares are observed as transient brightenings throughout the electromagnetic spectrum, lasting from a few seconds to hours. The way that this energy release occurs is poorly understood. This project will utilize 3D solar flare modeling and new observational data from the Expanded Owens Valley Solar Array (EOVSA) to better understand how magnetic reconnection leads to the release of magnetic energy and particle acceleration from solar flares. Software tools will be developed and upgraded and used to teach high school interns about solar physics and for graduate physics courses.

The project capitalizes on the unique ability of EOVSA to quantify evolution of solar flares by dynamically measuring coronal magnetic fields along with the thermal and nonthermal electron distributions with high spatial and temporal resolution. The following fundamental science goals will be addressed: (i) to understand and quantify the dynamics of solar flares of varying types, with an emphasis on the 3D spatial distribution and evolution of the coronal magnetic field and nonthermal particles; (ii) to obtain new fundamental knowledge on universal physical processes occurring on the Sun such as magnetic reconnection, particle acceleration and transport, and plasma heating. The team will provide open access to the research products to scientists and the public. The work utilizes new microwave imaging data from the EOVSA, data from other ground-based instruments, and data from the latest space missions, coupled with advanced modeling and forward-fitting, to obtain the three-dimensional magnetic field and particle distributions in flaring loops.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the project were (i) Understanding and quantifying the dynamics of solar flares of varying types, with an emphasis on the 3D spatial distribution and evolution of the coronal magnetic field and nonthermal particles; and (ii) Using these results to obtain new fundamental knowledge on universal physical processes occurring on the Sun such as magnetic reconnection, particle acceleration and transport, and plasma heating. Solar flares are commonly referred to transient brightenings in the solar atmosphere driven by release of free magnetic energy. A typical solar flare demonstrates substantial spatial complexity and time variability in both thermal and nonthermal components. Solar flares result from dissipation and transformation of magnetic free energy in the corona. Now, due to our pioneering contribution to the field, quantitative measurements of the coronal magnetic field on short flare time scales became possible. In addition, with the availability of EOVSA radio imaging spectroscopy, we added the direct measurements not only of the magnetic fields in flaring loops, but also plasma parameters to the data pool, which was crucial for addressing the project objectives. For the first time, we quantified in great detail how the released magnetic energy powered the solar flare including the discovered bulk acceleration of nonthermal electrons in the flare cusp region (Nature 2022). The project provided new knowledge on solar flares; new computer codes and simulation tools have been created or substantially upgraded. The project outcome is documented in 13 journal articles in scientific journals, and many conference contributions, which have garnered more than 100 citations.

Intellectual merit. We employed multi-wavelength data from radio to gamma-rays to investigate the relationships between the magnetic reconnection and signatures of particle acceleration to highest energies in one of the largest solar flares. We found that the main energy release and proton acceleration up to subrelativistic energies occur when the reconnection rate has passed over the maximum, following a major change of the flare topology. We developed the first-ever data-constrained and data-validated evolving model of a solar flare in the 3D domain, which permitted to investigate the energy partitions and evolution in great detail. We made a ground-breaking discovery of bulk electron acceleration in a strong, X-class solar flare. We found that the main energy release and electron acceleration happens in an extended cusp region, where a prominent decay of the magnetic field is accompanied by highly efficient particle acceleration. For a subset of solar active regions with an extremely strong coronal magnetic field, we discovered that their solar flares often produce dense giant post-flare loops clearly seen in high-frequency microwave images. This phenomenon permits probing the coronal plasma independently on the elemental abundances (unlike the EUV diagnostics) and estimating the coronal magnetic field at high heights of about 100 Mm. The modeling and analysis tools, GX Simulator, GSFIT, and GSFITVIEW were substantially upgraded.

Broader impacts. Within this project we continued the broader impact activity typical for our team. All project personnel have been trained in using the updated versions of interactive tools GX Simulator, 'GSFIT,' and 'GSFITVIEW'. Tutorial for other potential users of these products were performed during dedicated workshops held at NJIT in January 2023 and February 2024. Thirteen research papers were published. Many seminar and conference presentations have been delivered, which includes several invited / plenary talks. Numerous press-releases and media coverages highlighted our activities; in particular, the discovery of bulk electron acceleration in the cusp region in 2022. Several interviews were published by popular science resources. The measurements of evolving coronal magnetic field and nonthermal particle evolution can serve as proxies for other eruptive phenomena in other astrophysical environments. Our modeling tools are being used for in-class demonstrations. Our new 3D modeling, visualization, and analysis tools have a great level of generality, while are very simple in the use, having high level of interaction and great flexibility in setting up the geometry and plasma properties. These are highly helpful in the presentation and teaching along with the research in the solar physics. They represent the most general, flexible, and convenient modeling tools developed so far and freely available for the community. The tools are already widely used for immediate teaching goals in the Center.
